content.question:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions relating to the chemistry of the halogens.

(a) The molecular formulas of diatomic bromine, chlorine, fluorine, and iodine are written below. Circle the formula of the molecule that has the longest bond length. Justify your choice in terms of atomic structure.

<math alttext="B r 2, C l 2, F 2, I 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mtd><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mtd><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mtd><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions relating to the chemistry of the halogens.

(a) The molecular formulas of diatomic bromine, chlorine, fluorine, and iodine are written below. Circle the formula of the molecule that has the longest bond length. Justify your choice in terms of atomic structure.

<math alttext="B r 2, C l 2, F 2, I 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mtd><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mtd><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mtd><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

A chemistry teacher wants to prepare <math alttext="B r 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The teacher has access to the following three reagents: <math alttext="N a B r, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaBr</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="C l 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="I 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Half-Reaction
 <math alttext="E naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>°</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius, in volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>(V)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="B r 2 plus 2 electrons, produces, 2 B r with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="1.07" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.07</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="C l 2 plus 2 electrons, produces, 2 C l with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="1.36" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.36</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext=" I 2 plus 2 electrons, produces, 2 I with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="0.53" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.53</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

(b) Using the data in the table above, write the balanced equation for the thermodynamically favorable reaction that will produce <math alttext="B r 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> when the teacher combines two of the reagents. Justify that the reaction is thermodynamically favorable by calculating the value of <math alttext="E naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>°</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> for the reaction.

<math alttext="B r 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C l 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> can react to form the compound <math alttext="B r C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BrCl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) The boiling point of <math alttext="B r 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="332 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>332</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, whereas the boiling point of <math alttext="B r C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BrCl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="278 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>278</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Explain this difference in boiling point in terms of all the intermolecular forces present between molecules of each substance.

The compound <math alttext="B r C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BrCl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can decompose into <math alttext="B r 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C l 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, as represented by the balanced chemical equation below.

<math alttext="2 B r C l, gas, is in equilibrium with, B r 2, gas plus C l 2, gas, delta H naught equals 1.6 kilojoules per mole of reaction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>BrCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mtd><mtd><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mo>°</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1.6</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

A <math alttext="0.100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> mole sample of pure <math alttext="B r C l, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BrCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is placed in a previously evacuated, rigid <math alttext="2.00 liter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> container at <math alttext="298 Kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>298</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Eventually the system reaches equilibrium according to the equation above.

(d) Calculate the pressure in the container before equilibrium is established.

(e) Write the expression for the equilibrium constant, <math alttext="K sub equilibrium" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, for the decomposition of <math alttext="B r C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BrCl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

After the system has reached equilibrium, <math alttext="42" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>42</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent of the original <math alttext="B r C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BrCl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample has decomposed.

(f) Determine the value of <math alttext="K sub equilibrium" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math> for the decomposition reaction of <math alttext="B r C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BrCl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="298 Kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>298</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(g) Calculate the bond energy of the <math alttext="B r C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bond, in <math alttext="kilojoules per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, using <math alttext="delta H naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mo>°</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> for the reaction <math alttext="1.6 kilojoules per mole of reaction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1.6</mn><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and the information in the following table.

Bond
 Bond Energy <math alttext="in kilojoules per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>kJ/mol)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="B r B r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="193" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>193</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext=" C l C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="243" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>243</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="B r C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 ?

skill.text: 1.B: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate both particulate-level and macroscopic- level properties.
